Pretty pale malty body that is apparent through the huge hoppiness. Slightly citrusy, piney bush flavored hoppy taste. Very big flavor between the malts and huge hoppiness. Earthy, herbal hoppy finish that sticks around in the aftertaste.

Sappy, resinous pine drips from the glass.  Crystal clear straw colored with white foamy head.  Massive spruce, pine needle hop flavor; pitch like bitterness.  Malt is absent and hops are slightly sharp.  Mouthfeel is very delicate and light, perhaps a bit oily from the hops.  Mild carbonation.  Great DIPA.  Resinous hops throughout the taste.  Perhaps a bit of harsh bitterness compared to past years.  Alcohol noticeable on finish after about half of the glass.

Hate to be the one to say it, but the hype exceeds the reality. Had it again this year at RR on tap just after V-day. I just dont get all the fawning and exaggerated rankings. Its not a bad beer, but I could name 5 IPAs Id rather have in an instant, including two of their own - blind Pig and PtE. Now this is coming from an admitted "not an IPA lover" beer guy. Looks great, smells awesome, as I love the wall of hops your nose hits when sunk into the top of the glass. Thats where the love ends for me. Lack of malt balance and sweeter tinge wasnt appreciated. The aftertaste is lingering and not as pleasant as expected. Kinda tinny and alcohol based more than hoppy bitterness. Just not for me...

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2012 Tap @ Parkway 11 and 12. Clear gold pour with a short white head leaving coarse lace. Resinous, kaya nose with a hint of the sweet, heavy body and a strong ethanol premonition. Heavy body, medium carbonation with flavors of pine, ganja, and glucose. The ethanol bitterness spoils this one a bit for me. The mouth feel is tremendous - you can roll this one around in your mouth once it warms. Hint of tartness accompanies the long bitter finish and an alcohol burn is left in the gullet. I prefer the Elder. Re-rated 2/12. EtOH bitterness is much reduced and in direct comparison to the Elder I now prefer the Younger. This year its a shade heavier and smoother, with more pine aroma and more malty sweetness in the body. PtE has now ascended the throne of IIPAs!

Enjoyed a couple of these at the Falling Rock on Sunday afternoon. As my friend hophead21112 said the aroma of this beer is like a caramel covered grapefruit stuffed with hops. Which would be an accurate description of the aroma complete with subtle notes of eucalyptus and pine and beautiful floral undertones. Flawless color, shimmering golden hue with a light head of white bubbles which was a sight considering a very small flow of carbonated bubbles. A very bright mouth feel with citrus that hints at freshly squeezed oranges, followed by the subtle bitterness of hops and just the slightest sting of alcohol. These flavors combine beautifully to create a finish that lingers on the surface of the tongue. It made for a great Sunday. Thank you Russian River and cheers to the Pub Rat.

This is my first review on RB.  On tap at the RR Brewpub, amazing uprfront hop taste and mouthfeeel.  Plenty of Citrus and Pine with a huge bitter finish that worked perfect with nose and overall taste.  No Hype here, PTY is for real and super drinkable.  10.25% ABV and not hint of heat.

On tap at the Falling Rock today. Had enough to go around for me to try 2 snifters ($8 each). Pours a nice golden hue with low fluffy white head and minimal lacing. Sweet, citrus aroma with less pine than I remember from last years release, but still - what a nice nose. Could breath this one all day. Starts with a mild pine resin and citrus flavor, with pineapple and orange flavors coming on strong on the finish. Nice hop balance and tell-tale floral pine on the tongue. Beautiful stuff and incredibly balanced with minimal bitterness. Thanks to Chris for procuring this great brew again.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2011 Pours orange with white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, wood/resin dominate. Taste is sweet with a nice hop end.  Full bodied with oily texture.  This is a really nice DIPA that hides the abv well.  Quite drinkable.

draft at Russian River & Bistros IIPA tasting in Hayward, CA. Tried waiting the rating out to be the 500th rating but 499 will have to do. Very few hyped up beers i have had have met &/or exceeded expectations but this IIPA has.  Deeper Golden orange pour. Bitternss through the roof but still amazingly balanced. Strong at 10.25%+ but still incrediby drinkable. Big grapefruit, sticky hops, so balanced, delicious. Worth every $$$ it took for the trek from Buffalo to Santa Rosa, CA.

Thanks to Wes at the Verdugo for sharing part of his PtY with me.  Even amidst the hype, the beer community shines.  Floral and white grapefruit aroma.  Pours a dark orange which belies the lightness of the beer.  A quick hit of citrus bitterness almost fades then sticks at the back of the tongue.  Not carbonated but very light.

What more could I ask for in a beer? Got in line an hour early on a Wednesday morning at the Rose and Crown in Palo Alto. Got a tulip glass of this highly-hyped and highly-hopped brew. Never thought Id find a beer that made Pliny the Elder seem weak, but this is it. Smooth, amazing balance. Exceptionally hoppy, but wraps into a pleasant sweetness that is unique. Im a big fan, this is without a doubt the best beer Ive had.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 On tap at Toronado!!!  Check my facebook pics for an idea of what the worlds best triple IPA served at the worlds best Beer Bar looks like!!  The hop flavors are similar to the Elder, but with a massive malt backbone and pronounced caramel notes.  Well worth the 6 hour flight!!!!

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2011 I will change the score when I find a better beer. I enjoyed this beer because it was sooo similar to pliny the elder, yet bigger in every way possible. the malts were not prominent and the hops smashed the pallet but in a very gentle way. The bar went crazy when they ran out. I am grateful for the people who were there early and appreciate the beer. I will be around next year.

On tap at the Crow Bar in Corona del Mar, CA.  Poured a magnificent golden yellow color with minimal white head that laces the glass only slightly with each sip.  The aroma is not nearly as powerful as I was expecting but that isnt to say it isnt there. Just not to the level I was expecting.  Smelled fantastic with citrus at the front and some pine near the end.  The beer is incredibly drinkable and much too easy to put back at that ABV.  The hoppiness is there all around your mouth with minimal malt near the finish before the hops kick in once again.  Very, very good beer and classic for the style. I understand why this has the hype it does but other DIPAs out there a very comparable in my mind.  Not to take anything away from this fabulous beer.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: PP San Clemente.  Clear yellow/gold with a frothy white head that fades to resinous lacing down the glass.  Aroma is pungent clean hops, citrus, pine, sublte bitter hops, and perhaps a touch of tropical fruit.  Taste is liquid hops with resinous pine up front followed by citrus, light and delicate bready malt in the middle, and a clean, bitter hops presence through the finish.  Very light touch of alcohol on the finish.  Ultra drinkable.  Not the most pungent hop-heavy beer Ive had but the tightness and precision of the aroma/flavor profile is stunning.

Growler sent by joeneugs (last year-rating from notes)  Pours a clear dark golden/orange color with a medium sized off white head.  There was a big pop when we opened the growler.  The aroma was everything I would want in a DIPA: an explosion of hops containing pine, pineapple, clementine, apricot, resin, ...!  The flavor brings much of the same: pine, resin, citrus, lemon, grapefruit, pineapple, and caramel malts to try and off-set the bitterness.  The alcohol remains hidden throughout.  Medium, somewhat oily texture, dry, so easy to drink; great mouthfeel.  I had wanted to try this since I joined the sight and it did not disappoint.  This is everything a DIPA should be and more.  My next step is to make it out to the San Fran area when it is on tap.

At Toronado, Haight St., SF to kick off "SF Beer Week 2011."  On a hunch, I biked over to Toronado for the Friday Happy Hour.  I was shut-out of the limited supply of Younger during Beer Week 2010, so I was pleased to find this available before the Twitter crowd caught wind.

Disclaimer: Im not a big fan of the IPA style (let alone double & triple), so Im not the best choice to judge this beer.  However, Pliny the Younger doesnt disappoint.  Ive tried several extreme IPAs from SoCal brewers, and theyve left me almost traumatized by the hop hit.  RR pairs the assertive flavor of the hops with 11% ABV to produce a masterpiece of beer culture.  This chance encounter bodes well for the rest of SF Beer Week 2011.

Draft at Pliny Day 2011 (or week?). Pours orange with a nice white head which leaves good lacing and rentention. Aroma is grassy, floral, pine, citrus. Flavor is surprisingly balanced with a good amount of candy sugar/caramel malt to match the hops but still leaves some booziness. I described it as like biting into a mango. Improves as it warms.

Thoughts on this beer: I think its overhyped, but its definitely one of the best DIPAs Ive had and should only be drunk fresh at the brewery. However, I found myself walking away enjoying the sours at RR a lot more.

On tap at Russian River, 2011 release.  Pours an orangish amber, with a just a little bit of orangish white head that never really dissipates. The nose is overwhelmed by hops - resinous, pine, grapefruit, and even some pineapple/apricot esters. Very little malt character, just a little hint of toast.  Taste is suprising, you get the initial knock over the head of resinous and pine hops, but theres enough caramel and bready malt there to give it balance. Then the magic happens as you get some really nice fruity notes, grapefruit, dried apricot and pineapple overtaking the initial bitterness lingering into a really nice, lightly bitter finish.  Theres not a sense of any alcohol, which is dangerous as this comes in at slightly over 10% ABV.  A great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2012 On tap at Russian River. 2011.  Pours a golden amber with a small white head leaving a ridiculous amount of lacing on the glass for the alcohol content.  Aroma is ridiculous with resinous pine hops, loads of floral hops, and hints of pineapple and grapefruit.  Barely any malt coming through in the aroma.  Initial taste is huge pine hops going into some more floral hops with just enough malt to balance it.  A bit of grapefruit comes through as well.  Great bitterness on the finish, but not too much.  Medium body. Medium carbonation.  Amazingly not overly sweet or syrupy for a beer of its size like many DIPAs.  Amazingly drinkable as well.  This could very easily put you on the floor very quickly.  Just an amazingly good beer.  Worthy of all the hype it gets. 10/5/5/18

On tap at Bobby Gs.  2012 edition.  Pours a clear golden with a small white head that settles to a ring and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big pine, grapefruit, dank, hints of pineapple, orange, and some light caramel.  Smells quite bitter.  The initial taste is bitter with pine and grapefruit.  Quite dank and sticky.  There is also orange and pineapple.  Just enough caramel malt to give some balance to the huge amounts of hops.  The finish is very bitter and dry with just a bit of alcohol.  Medium body.  Dry.  Medium carbonation.  Just an amazing beer.  There is no other double or triple IPA this big that still manages to be dry. 9/4/9/5/18
Had this a while back, makes the elder look weak... Huge hop aroma, flavor is citrusy and bitter, amazingly good... Cant remember all the details, really good though

I had this on tap at The Kitchen in Boulder, Co sometime in mid-2009. I was working in the kitchen and we had the much expected pony keg. The GM brought me a glass to try....talk about a great job. At the time, i was just starting to be enthralled with beer, so I dont think I appreciated this Hoppy-God! But I know I was amazed how it smelled. How can a beer smell like this? It was so sweet and hoppy. The pour was absolutely gorgeous...clear and sparkling with small bubble. I dont think Ive ever loved a Double IPA before. but did I ever!

As with the ELDER...still one beer i dont totally understand the infatuation with...Id rather have a Blind Pig.  Had out of a growler from the most recent release...and from a couple of taps in san diego and oc over the past few years.  not what i look for in a dipa...overly sweet and chalky.  Still pretty good though.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap at Union Jacks Easter Hopfest on 04.03.2010.

A: Poured a pale apricot with a very nice, fluffy white head with loads of lacing as it goes down.

S: Bitter hops apparent from the beginning. Mostly tropical--mango and pineapple, mostly--alongside some grapefruit and other citrus notes. Not an iota of malt sweetness in the background.

T: Mango, pineapple, grapefruit, and apricot come from the hops. Apparently I need a hop break, as this one was bitter, but I didnt detect it much at all. The bitterness really complemented the fruitiness of the beer. Interesting "fruit" character, as the hops provided plenty of fruity characteristics without any actual sweetness.

M: Medium bodied, fairly dry, and good carbonation.

D: Amazing that I finally got to try this one after having so many things fall through this year. Looking forward to having it again next year, when I may just have to go straight to the source.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 04-04-2010

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Updating for February 2011 release: This years release is better balanced. I dont feel that the sweetness is too overpowering. Its almost like a very hoppy golden barleywine. Delicious, resiny, hoppy, sort of a honey taste, a hint of minerals. Bit of alcohol burn. Heavy sweetness, but less so than last year and relatively balanced with the bitterness. Surprisingly drinkable. Much more drinkable than last year.
Tap at RR on release date in 2010: Awesome, but a bit overrated. A bit unbalanced with too much sweetness. Tons of hops, of course.

This is what beer drinking is all about. Enthralling orange pour with aromas of honey, floral grassy hops, and heaven. The second the godly liquid touched my tongue, I rolled my eyes, dropped to my knees and worshiped The Hop. (I just Discovered what the "H" stands for in Jesus H Christ) It stands for HOP! The taste in this ambrosia is well blended citrus, pine and alcohol. A+ Work!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 I slayed a growler of this last night with the help of the other Matt. Weapon of choice was my Stone IPA tulip. I obtained a growler in a trade with great BA. As a result of our heroic undertaking, my mind is still not firing on all cylinders, but this is the best DIPA Ive ever had and only my second straight 5.

Beer poured from a Russian River growler into a Stone IPA tulip. Beer is yellow to orange and CLEAR! The pour forms a white head about an inch to a half an inch in thickness that falls away leaving some lacing on the glass. Carbonation is moderate to high and really steady. The bubbles nucleate at the bottom of the glass mostly, beginning small but rise slowly increasing in size as they rise to the head. The head retention is good. No chill haze, beautiful color, good head dynamics, nice level of carbonation, its a beautiful beer.

Aroma is primarily a lot of hops....a lot of hops. Very citrusy with some pine notes in there. There is some sweetness, its a dominate aroma component. Its difficult but sometimes I think I can smell some alcohol but mostly I can not. For being such a huge beer, I really cant tell based on the aroma at all. The aroma is also huge. I can smell it from across the table. I found myself not even drinking it just smelling it, very complex, very big, very wonderful.

Taste time, balance. This beer hits all the parts of the palate, forward, middle and back. Obviously there is hop bitterness in the back, there is some sweetness up front, but no alcohol. Beer is medium bodied, definitely not a malt bomb like some DIPAs tend to be. There are almost fruit notes in the mid-palate. Some sweet orange or almost lime flavors. Beer finishes cleanly, leaving no aftertaste. Bitterness grows as it does with most big hoppy beers, but it does not interfere with the other flavors or drinkability.

I was going to originally rate the drinkability as a 4.5 for this beer. But I had some food between my pints of it and after some food a blew through my second pint. It is an amazingly balanced and completely wonderful IPA. At 11%, it is unlikely that I would make it my daily drinker, but it is the most dangerously drinkable 11% beer Ive ever had.

EDIT: I had this again at EBF (4 ounce pour) and compared it side by side with Pliney the Elder. I realized as Matt and I were drinking this growler that it was an important but absent variable in my review is comparing it to another beer. We drug out an Exponential Hoppiness for comparison but it wasnt the right thing to do.

At the fest I had 4 ounces of each next to each other. My wife and I both tasted each and agreed that Younger was better than Elder. It was sweeter and thicker, had more fruit notes on the palate and smells were uncomparable. The hop aroma on Younger blew the hop aroma on Elder out of the water. Im not going to write an additional review of this beer on draft, I just thought I would include these thoughts in my present review.

Serving type: growler

Growler.Pours a clear golden color with a small fast disappearing off-white head. Has a fruity fresh malty hoppy grapefruit and peach aroma. Malty hoppy bitter grapefruit, peach and pnie needles flavor. Has a long malty hoppy bitter grapefruit and peach finish, with a long bitter aftertaste.

Believe the hype.  I chased this beer all around town when it was around a few months ago and it was well worth it.  

It came to Bishops Collar, Monks and a few other places.  

Ridiculously amazing beer.  If I had my choice of anything at anytime, this would be it.

Growler, shortly after this crazy release.  I was lucky enough to try this twice after the release and it definitely lived up to the hype.  It pours with a glowing orange color, a lasting head, and a sticky lacing.  Aroma is soo, soo sweet... hops-sweet that is, love this sweet hops.  It is really a beautiful mix of sweet sugars and sweet bubble gum hops. So, its not sugary but more like sweet bubble gum hops.  Flavor is the same with some bitterness cutting through the beer.  This is accompanied by a thicker and lightly sticky mouthfeel which works well with the structure of the beer.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
Like a walk thru a hop orchard with grapefruit and orange trees all around, except the hops arent quite ripe, ...if you will.

Very nice. EXTREMELY interesting but I found it not quite as satisfying as its neighboring brewerys Lagunitas Hop Stoopid, nor as drinkable.

I truly respect what theyve brewed there at Russian River, and I WILL buy more, but I only desire it when I want to tantalize my taste buds like going on a rollercoaster ride or enjoying a slice of sickeningly sweet wedding cake, you just cant do it all the time or it would lessen the impact and an heir of out-of-balance feeling might set in.

This is a real taste adventure and one I highly recommend you put near the top of your Not-to-miss-beers list, but if I visit you for the weekend Id like one or two bottles of Pliny, and fourteen bottles of Hop Stoopid - thank you very much, and do not forget several chilled beer steins populating your freezer.

BTW, I rarely give more than a 3.

I had this on tap several times this February, and thoroughly enjoyed it. Its Elder but more, in fact so much more that I think it loses all the charm. Where Elder is thought out and refined and has all the right hops in the right amounts with just enough malt to make it all okay, Younger is the most aromatic hoppy beer youve ever had then doubled in hops.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2016 Light golden, with some straw tones... solid white head, quality retention and lacing... when I walked into the bar they had just started pouring this... nearly everyone went right for the younger (also had elder, consecration, blind pig, damnation, salvation, and rejection on draft)... you can spot this beer across the bar and its so appetizing... ordered it up and waited for the keg to kick in roughly a half hour.  Powerful citrus hop blast, mostly grapefruit but hints of tangerine... not as much pine as the elder, but certainly in abundance. Incredibly balanced... sure the hops are crazy strong with intense pine and grapefruit, with a nice resiny bite, but this beer has the smoothest flavoring ever... the malt is soft, slightly sweet, and has a real nice character to it... Super smooth. Crisp finish. Dry hop bite.  I looked down after about five minutes and I was halfway through my glass.
the holy grail of all that is hop. possibly the most perfectly balanced beer ever made. elegant. graceful. magnificent.

Draft @ Colins Pub; dusted off notes from the 2009 release as the 2010 release was gone in a blink of an eye; dark orange and clear with trace white head leaving some sticky lacing; nothing subtle with big time hop juice aromas and you can just smell the bitterness; quite harsh on first sip and sugary; bitterness overwhelms just about everything and this is more of a decedent treat than a beer to drink much off; and the bitterness to me is just a little much and I find Elder much more my style

2/24/2010:  Russian River Pliny the Younger...  Aroma:  Vibrant hop aroma containing pine, pineapple, clementine, spruce, and more!  Appearance:  Clear, brilliant yellow color; plenty of off-white foam on the top; average carbonation (the flip-top on the growler popped like a gunshot).  Flavor:  Bright and hoppy, BITTER!  Sharp pine, resin, citrus concentrate, lemon, ; alcohol completely hidden.  Palate:  Medium-light; oily texture; sucks the moisture from the mouth; lovely mouthfeel; DELICIOUS!  Overall:  This is truly a DOUBLE IPA in all regards: alcohol, hops, bitterness!  Wow in the world do they get so much bitterness and alohol in such a light and easy to drink beer?!  This is what all Imperial/Double IPAs should aspire to be!  There is no doubt that this beer lives up to its hype!
Growler (draught) shared by alesdad06.  Thank you Brad.  I appreciate it!  Rating #472 for this beer.

It smelled VERY strongly of hops.  My nose is not fancy enough to decipher the different scents - to me, it was just super hoppy.  It was light amber/gold, with no real head to speak of.  It was sweet and watery when sipped, but had a syrupy feel on my lips afterward.  It was nice, sweet, and subtle.  Overall, the first half of the glass was really nice.  However, after that...it just stopped being all that great.  Maybe the hops killed my palate, I dont know.  But its not a beer I would drink a lot of.

Growler. 2009 vintage. 

Pours a golden orange with red hues and a small off-white head. 

The aroma is a bit shy at first, but looses up after a while. fruity exotic hop notes of grapefruit, peaches and mango. Then, a more peppery and piny hop character with hints of tobacco takes over. Quite a lot of caramel malts is present, as well is a hint of alcohol. 

The flavor is big and intense. A wide range of flavors are present: sweet and sticky caramel malts at the base, and lots of layers of fresh hops. Exotic fruits, pine-needles, grass and resins. The finish is spectacular with a quick flare of warming alcohol, lots of bittering hops and hints of grass and peaches. 

Full-bodied and sticky with a semi-dry finish.

This is a great beer. Better than Elder? Hard to decide, but the accentuated sweetness in this one sure makes them different.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2010 Draft, first at EBF. Orange pour with a lacing of white head. Huge citrus, pine and pineapple aromas. Flavor follows with some warming. Aftertaste is enjoyable, and it lingers for a bit. Nice.

A - served in a tulip glass
S - Very hoppy, citrus and floral
T - tasted hops and orange...great representation of style just perfect
M - after it warmed it was incredible, balanced from start to finish
D - excellent beer just perfect

A- Body is a minimally translucent bright amber/orange color. Pours with about a 1/2 finger white foamy head that eventually subsides to a nice thick collar.

S- Absolutely heavenly. Bright juicy grapefruit and citrus are the main character and it has a balance of a slightly sharp piny character.

T- Wonderful. A big bright kick of juicy citrus and sharp pine flavors come through first with equal strength. A sweet malt provides the backbone for this and is completely overshadowed-but still detectable. The pine intensifies for the finish keeping the intensity of this brew up. What lingers is a slight alcohol heat and a medium strength residual rind bitterness.

P- Well carbonated. Medium weight oily body. The oiliness is wonderful but a bit of alcohol astringency can be detected also.

O- This is an absolutely wonderful DIPA that I thought I would never get the opportunity to try. Its an intense experience that goes right to the top without going over the top (as many Hop-bombs due). Its just barely kept in check.

Serving type: growler

Reviewed on: 02-18-2009 13:19:14

This beer is definitely the pinnacle of IPAs. The IPA has a beautiful caramel color, similar to an old German Riesling and a wonderful hop aroma that makes you feel as if youre running through a field of hop vines. The taste embodies the classic characteristics of a West Coast IPA with strong presence of bittering hops resembling Chinook. The mouthfeel is amazing, very smooth and fully bodied with less carbonation than a typical West Coast which improves its drinkability. You can easily suck back several pints of the Younger without worrying that your taste buds will be recked. Overall, an amazing IPA worth the status of number one Beer on the Planet

Orange pour with white head and lace. Huge citrus/resiny aroma. Sweet malt, citrus/resin flavor. Medium bodied with good carbonation. A very well balanced beer. The hop profile is tempered well with the malt. Very nice beer.

Growler at RBWG. So glad I finally got to try this one. This one certainly lives up to the hype. This one looks and smells the part of an extremely hoppy IPA. It pours a mostly clear and glowing orange-amber color and topped by a foamy, off white head that shows good retention. The head leaves a sudsy wash of lace in its wake. The aroma is bursting with hops of the citrus and dank pine varieties. Orange, bitter grapefruit, mango, and pine resin all rush to the front and as potent as I have ever smelled. The malt base is of sweet toffee and add just enough sweetness to all hop bitterness. The flavor follows the same and is just as enticing as the nose suggests. Orange, bitter grapefruit, and pine resin bitterness from the hops rush to the forefront, but the balance of the sweet toffee malt lends to making this easy to drink. All the hops crush the palate with bitterness, but all the flavors combine to make this a really tasty brew. The body is big and viscous, and quite sticky from all the hops, but finishes off pretty clean with a nice bitter citrus finish. This is just an awesome IPA, and I hope to have it again sometime.

Is there a more generous Ratebeerian out there than Brad?  Some of the best beers Ive had a chance to try have been thanks to him.  Big shout out to ygtbsm94.  The Russian River genie growler pours a cloudy orange, amber with a very frothy white head.  Nose is fresh hops, Columbus hops, Simcoe hops.  Honestly, home brewers out there will know what I mean, this smells like a handful of dusty, resinous hop pellets.  Truthfully, it smells like Bells Hopslam.  Flavor is citrus fruits, oranges, grapefruits, caramel candies, lightly metallic.  Finish is full bodied, sweet, citrus bitterness.  Very, very good.  Is it worth the hype?  Hmmm... maybe.

Wonderful. Its chock full of hop flavor. Ive had a number of DIPAs, and this beer expresses hop flavor better than any beer that Ive ever tasted. Hops are the star in the flavor department. They are citric, piny and very floral. The citrus is grapefruit, orange and tangerine mixed with pineapple. The pine is dark and resiny, like sap. There is a strong malt backbone that allows this much hop flavor to come through. Is this beer balanced? I would say so, but the malt does not express the same complexity and assertiveness of the hops. That is not to say the malt isnt strong or is bad. The malt is actually wonderful. Its like a caramel cookie swirled into a fine hop tea.  The color is very close to Elder and Blind Pig, which is to say golden-amber and wonderful. The aroma is very hoppy, with the flavors as previously described. The feel is also exceptional, almost oily with hop essence.

Growler courtesy of tarheels86, thank you sir.  Clear amber color, white head, nice lacing.  Aroma of pine cones and white pepper.  Taste is bitter throughout, some citrus, decent balance.  Others at the tasting complained regarding freshness, but I enjoyed this one thoroughly.

Based on 4 10 oz drafts at Resurrection Ale House and Local 44 in Philly:
It pours a copper, golden orange w. good carbonation, a decent, albeit thin head w. lacing all the way down the glass.
The nose is a floral, citrus, hoppy explosion with pineapple, orange, lemon zest but especially grapefruit. 
The taste, while not what I would describe as complex, was just...well...perfection - bitterness perfectly offset by sweetness and malt and a peppery grapefuit fresh aftertaste. There is evidence of the alcohol in the warming finish but no hint of the 11% (so beware!).
In short, maybe there is a better beer out there somewhere, but I have yet to find it; This is an awesome beer.  In fact, having now over 320 different beers, this is THE best beer. period, Hands down.
-
Growler. Thanks to Erik and Filip. Wonderful hoppiness, herbs, green leaves, grass, citrus, woody. Sweet malt, peaches, orange, caramell . Very komplex and powerful

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Growler courtesy of ygtbsm94. Wow! Thought I would have to sell my soul at some point to have some of this. Pours a clear orange with a thick, enormous yellow head. Great retention and lace. Aroma is fresh citrus hops, pineapple, papaya, raw Simcoe whole cones. Taste is very bitter, lots of past-their-prime tropical hops, orange juice, orange peel. The 130 IBUs or whatever makes the 11% undetectable. Overall this is insanely bitter rather than fresh and fruity. Im sure that this is not in its ultra freshest state and that it would be a knock-out on tap. But it is a little ridiculous that some of these top IPAs and DIPAs have a half-life of 48 hours and then fall apart. 4/5/2010 9/4/7/4/14=3.8Tap at Russian River for PtY 2011. The pour is a clear, deep orange with a small, white head that leaves some big sheety lace. The aroma on PtY is a little hard to get at served in the miniature English pint glass. But once it warms up a bit you get some serious jackfruit, bitter mango, candied oranges, fresh orange. Taste is fresh mango hoppy like biting into a raw mango. Lots of bitter mango skin and juicy mango pulp. Dank, fruity tropicals abound but the seriously dense body here is hard to get through. Some quick, spicy alcohol is present but a non sequitor. Obviously the king of DIPAs, but that doesnt mean it has to be my favorite. 2/5/2011 9/4/8/4/16=4.1 Tap at PtY 2012. Served in a miniature nonic pint glass, it pours a sparkling, clear brilliant orange pour with minuscule white foam. Minimal lace. Nose is hydroponic marijuana with tangerine and Asian fruits: rambutan, jackfruit, lychee. Taste has some alcohol, minimal "bitterness", tangy tangerine and sweet rambutan. Decently chewing with fresh, underripe mango flesh. Yummy. Not special enough to warrant a giant line for two weeks. But its worth it for the sour anthology tap takeover. :) Wheres the Compunction this year???????!!!!!!

Second to last glass at Union Jacks Hop fest today, pours a beautiful golden clear color with slight head and lacing. The nose is phenominal with pine, citrus, and floral scents.  First sip is pure heaven with huge malt but quick bold hop flavor also happens. The finish is crisp and clean this year with less booze flavor than in the past. Truely a remarkable beer. I was so lucky to get one this year.

Growler. Thanks to Amy and John for my first taste of this and Matt for my second. Aroma is citrus, candied orange peel and light pine. Taste is candied orange peel and some pine. Bracing bitterness. Tasty.

Interesting story behind this rating. A friend poured this into a bottle with a small funnel when it was on draft at The Grey Lodge or somewhere. I had it a few days later. Im sure it was better fresh and Ill have to try this again sometime.  Pours a deep caramel honey colour with a white head. Aroma of pine, bitter hops,  citrus. Flavour of pine, bitter hops, malt, and citrus.

Sample @ EBF.  Pours a hazy straw color with a white head.  Aroma is largely grapefruit with a bit of pine hops.  Taste is an EXPLOSION of citrus and pine hops, with the alcohol amazingly well-hidden.  The flavors are so intense, its incredible....I love IPAs, and I love hops...this beer is close to hophead perfection.

Had from a growler at RBWG 2010.  Easily the best DIPA Ive ever had.  Amazing fresh hop flavor there with earthiness, citrus, floral, and more. The flavor is right up there as well, plenty of hop and bitterness but enough malt so its not a crazy unbalanced mess. Love it!
Awesome growler pour at RBWG. Hazy light gold pour. Huge resiny pine and citrus aroma, simply intoxicating. Medium thick malt with a huge grapefruit pine bitterness. Stunningly good.

had it at rrbrewpub and out of the 2 growlers brought home what an amazingly hopped beer ive never had 120 minute so as of right now this is the holy grail for hopheads made it a mission from southern cali up to the bay area hit thirsty bear 21st amendment and lagan.. but rr was the best 
besides it looking like tickets for prince were going on sale and 3 hour wait 
this beer is worth the hype

RBWG 2010 growler. Pours hazy golden orange color with white head. Strong aroma of grapefruit and pine. Sweet and bitter grapefruit flavor with some piney notes and alcohol. Medium body with average carbonation. Awesome!

Thanks to Maltzilla for sharing a growler at RBWG2010!!
Wow!  Big hoppy nose with floral, citrus, and pine notes in perfect harmony.  This resinous nectar pours golden with a small white head.  The taste is an oh-so-satisfyingly intense version of the aroma that ignites the taste buds and finishes with a long dry, bitter finish with a little heat from the alcohol, but nowhere near as much as expected.  Im reviewing this days later and I can still taste it!  The mouth-feel is sticky and body medium.  Im learning that I prefer the cleaner, thinner, lighter qualities of single IPAs and hoppy pale ales, but this beer is amazing enough to bring back my old zeal in the over-the-top hop-bomb category.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2011 2011 younger day, 30oz to my dome. nice stuff, this years was 10.25% abv, so it was slightly more managable! lol! drinks nice and smooth, very hoppy and syrupy, like hop essential oil or something. its definitely one of the best iipas in the world, but its still not worth the hassle imo.

golden yellow with huge white head.  hop nose of floral, herbal, citrus mostly.  moderate mouthfeel and carbonation.  firm bitterness before the above mentioned hop flavor, amazingly powerful before a shockingly dry finish, very little alcohol that adds depth only.  compared next to pliny the elder which really tasted like water in comparison.  superb

Growler thanks to someone at RBWG. Nose is just insane stupid amount of hops with some noticable alcohol. Flavor is huge citrus up front and some noticable malt and alcohol to back things up and then a huge wall of bitterness just assaults your pallate. To much for me. Ill take the Elder any day.

Beautiful smell. 10oz glass at nakedcity brewpub in greenwood. The smell is even better then the taste. Amber hoppy nectar but is it really better then a green flash IIPA or Founders Devil Dancer or Black Raven wisdomseeker? Worth the wait but too much hype.

rDev: +1.1%

So friends of mine asked me what good beer I had around and I popped open a growler of younger. After half a glass, the double digit ABV frightened them off, and I was left with half a growler. I cant complain because this is a beautiful beer. It Poured a nice amber color, almost like mead, With a good solid head and an all hop aroma. The taste was exquisite with a heavy hop forward bitter blast, balanced out by a honey/nectar malt flavor. I had 3 glasses and I could drink this alll night if it were not for the alcohol hitting me after glass 3. Its an amazing beer!

On tap at the brewery on 2010 release day.  OK, I have been waiting a long time to get this and after not being able to get any last year, made it a mission.  My eldest son and I flew to San Fran to begin our Cali beer quest on Thursday, the day before the release.  Drove up in a rental car and got to the brewery around 1:00PM.  Was worried because the line was long and not moving.  Apparently, everyone that got in around opening at 11:00 were still inside having a good time.  After a two-hour wait, we made it into the pub and got a table.  First off, we ordered glasses of Younger.  The anticipation and hype were so high, I was hoping I wouldnt be disappointed.  We werent.  This brew is magical.  Simply heavenly.  It pours a beautiful golden with a thin white head.  The nose was of grass and pine and just about perfect.  The taste.  Well, the taste was perfect.  It was of pine and grass and I could have drank it all day.  Lovely.  The mouthfeel was fantastic too.  It was creamy, yet tingly with a mouth-grabbing bitterness and bite to it.  I could drink this all the time and never get tired of it.  This was a beautiful beer-drinking experience.  One of my top-five of all time.  Luckily, i was able to get three growlers, two of which I traded and one for myself and the Houston RBers.  Wish I could get this every year.
Pours a cloudy tarnished yellow.  Sharp hoppy nose.  Resinous, piny, with hints of citrus peel.  Very dry and very bitter.  Hops reign supreme.  A very excellent IPA.

Oh man hops, hops, hops, huge floral hop nose with caramel-like malts in the background.  Pours a golden blonde with a thin white head.  Big piney sticky grapefruty hop flavor up front, earthy bitterness with hints of malts in there as well.  The hops definitely dominate which theyre supposed to in this case.  Very nice.

Draft: golden amber with a thin white head, amazing citrus and hoppy aroma, dry bitter hoppy taste with citrus.  I can still feel the warming traits of this beer an hour later while I am home typing this up.  This beer is way over hyped but good.

Handbottle from Irishboy.  Thanks a ton, Richard!!!Pours a beautiful, thick and sappy amber with a light head.  Nose is grapefruit pine syrup with a touch of orange coffee.  Perhaps a big of citrus cigar ash, too?  Flavor is a restrained rush of grapefruit, strawberry, orange pulp, and pine.  Its very aggressive but never overwhelming or offensive.  Superbly balanced yet assertive; it demands your attention but doesnt resort to annoying you with ridiculous and obsurb attention-grabbing tactics, kinda like the anti-Dane Cook.  Nice, full mouthfeel that leaves residue long after the sip is over.  One of the best IPAs available.  Thanks again, Richard!  Slainte!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 Growler shared by Dave (dukedevil0), thank you sir! Poured into a tasting glass a couple of times.

A - Pours a golden/orange/copper color with a small white head. Theres lots of lacing around the sides of the glass, sticky stuff! Theres some head here and there on top of the beer, but just a hint here and there.

S - Very complex with lots going on here! Tropical fruit, smokey malts, straight-forward citrus, sweetness.

T - Mostly a malty sweetness mixed with a large amount of hops. The hops are def there, but its not overdone. A nice bitter finish. 

M - Light, smooth, clean finish. Nice carbonation, just frothy enough to let you know its there but not enough to take away from the beer itself. 

D - So so easy to drink, its scary! Probably wont have another glass until 2011 unless I get lucky again.

I wasnt totally blown away by this beer as some others are. Its as good as Elder, probably neck and neck. Would have been nice to have them both for a side by side. I think I prefer Elder to Younger...

Growler thanks to pantanap!!!!! Pours a clear glowing golden, clear but with substance, similar to hopslam, thin bubbly head.  Bright stingy peachy aroma, similar to Averys Dugana, light honey, faint biscuit, grapefruit, very well balanced but strong, floral, hops are nicely sharp, very clean sweetness.  Flavor follows, so very much like hopslam but much cleaner, the malt profile is definitely way more in check and together, lightly grapey, strong bitterness, very strong.  Well balanced, medium bodied, smoothly viscous, very smooth, fizzy carbonation, clean.

Had this on tap at Vine Street Pub. Pour was a crystal clear golden with a disappointing tan head. Nose was strongly of musk melon and honey. Obvious grass and grapefruit as well.  Tasting it brought out bubblegum and a little caramel. Not unexpectedly it had a sharp bitter finish with an equally not surprising sweetness. The alcohol came through more then I like but it was not over whelming, very good for 11%.  Low carbonation and thick feel. An extremely drinkable beer, with a great nose and a delightful taste but maybe, just maybe a little overrated.

Ah the trials and tribulations of tracking down one of the most elusive double ipas around. It was a story to be told to the grandkids. Whatever happened though was definitely worth all the trouble and agony. Hop profile is incredibly dynamic and diverse. It keeps a nice balance all the way through though as well despite being so overly hopped up. Grassy and citrus aroma. Flavor is mostly hop citrus and the finish is a bitter metallic grapefruit sort of thing. Nice body and caramel malt work throughout. Some soapy flavor as well. Slightly sweet.

Growler. Pours orange with a thick tan head. Nose is ridiculous citrus, pine, floral hops melded with sweet caramel and toffee. Big fruit esters. Flavor is sweet but not cloying, tons of caramel and sweet hops flavors. Hints of alcohol, pineapple, green apple, oranges, lemon, flowers. Insane!

Growler shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear bright copper color with a large frothy off-white head that was lasted with excellent lacing. Heavy complex sour citrus hop and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with dry slick texture and soft carbonation. Heavy smooth bitter citrus flavor with a heavy bitter finish of long duration with a small alcohol burn as it warms. This is a standout beer. Thanks Brad.
An incredible double IPA.  Hops are everywhere--great texture and almost a pasteurized mouthfeel.  Growler courtesy of the Tampa beer tasting crew.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 On tap at the Falling Rock in Denver and out of a kick ass growler thanks to Bill. Both times the experience was the same. Pours a crystal clear, golden body with a creamy, finger-width, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a veil of lacing throughout the session. The aroma is incredible. Tons of fresh, dank, oily hops. Resiny pines, sweet citrus, passion fruit, mango, florals, dense earth, herbs, and melons with a touch of caramel. A fantastic aroma. Flavor is a hop explosion as well and fairly sweet. Tons of bright, piney, grassy citruses, wet and dank earth, flowery tropical fruits, resins, a touch of honey, and a decent amount of caramel. Finishes dry and bitter with a very lengthy, oily, and resiny aftertaste. Medium body with a moderate carbonation. Not a bad balance at all for such an explosion of hops and no hint of alcohol until a slight warmth shows up in the throat. Overall, this definitely lives up to the hype. Hoppy as shit with an outstanding aroma. A pleasure both from the tap and the growler. Awesome DIPA.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Slightly hazed golden, amber color with a fingers worth of white foam that sticks around forever and leaves some nice lacing. The hops are amazingly intense with aromas of bitter grapefruit and pine. Quite a bit of caramel malt. The flavor is quite resinous, bitter, and piney with plenty of bitter grapefruit. Moderate sweetness of caramel and sugar. Lots of grapefruit, lemon, and pineapple.

On tap at Capones. Pours a beautiful oragne color with a just a bit of white head. Has a nice smell of citrus and a little pine. At first taste you get a bit of citrus but then it goes to a major bitter taste. Good beer but really bitter on the finish. Not sure if its worth all the hype but its a pretty good beer and Im glad I had it. Not RRs best brew by far.

Rating 1600, though I actually had it four beers prior, but seemed a better milestone beer. Pouring at session one of EBF in Boston.  Pours a mostly clear orange gold with a medium sized white head.  Awesome hop aroma, huge citrus and pine, big pineapple note.  Big, sweet, resinous, tastes like hop cones.  Long, long, long grapefruit finish.  Had a couple of this one.  Remarkably good.

Thanks Joey for this opportunity! Pours deep orange with thin but lasting white head.  Got a nice side by side pour with Pliny the Elder.  First though, the aroma is HUGE citrusy hops, can almost chew them from the smell.  Hints of orange, grapefruit, pine, resin throughout.  Taste is terrific, huge resin, pine, and citrus hops intermingle well to give a bit of sweetness, leads into a bit of caramel sweetness that lasts fairly long.  Ending is a bit dry and leaves a lasting bitterness in your mouth.  And there is no alcohol in the taste, totally hidden.  Awesome brew, best of the style Ive had yet.  

Side by side with Pliny the Elder, colors are very similar, if anything PTY is a bit darker/fuller.  Aroma is the similar types of hops, but the taste is definitely different.  A thinner taste from PTE with not as much balancing sweetness and a more harsh bitter differs from PTY which is a bit sweeter and more well balanced. Different, but both excellent brews.

Fortunate enough to sample this side by side with the Elder (thanks jrob!)--really nice to be able to contrast the two in the same session. Nose and flavor are huge hops, as expected--strong citrus and grapefruit, but not exclusive, as there were also more piney hops present.  Wonderfully supported by a robust malty backbone that balances the bitterness perfectly. Sweeter than the Elder. Alcohol present on the finish. An awesome beer, cant really imagine it being any better than it is.

Had at Capones, poured a hazy golden hue.  Minimal head.  Aroma is strong grapefruit, pine and damp earth.  Very well balanced mouthfeel, starts sweet and finishes bitter with nice crispness.  Hops dominate this beer.  The hype is well deserved, this is an excellent brew that I am lucky to have tried.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2010 On tap at Capones (9oz).  Enjoyed  with Leafs93 and Damico.  Pours an amber orange color, clear, with a thin head.  Has an aroma of pine and grapefruit.  This was definitely worth the anticipation.  Has a great taste, creamy smooth balance of bitter and sweet.  Notes of citrus.  I think what separates this imperial from other imperials is the creaminess.  I love the harsh hop bitters in imperials but the complex flavors here are balanced so well to reduce that harshness.  Which is likely what makes it so appetizing to so many beer fans.  I will not say it is the best beer I have ever had.  But it is near the top of my list.

Pours a dark golden orange/tangerine color with golden orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger fluffy, soapy white head that has amazing retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Soapy chunks of white lacing are left behind.

Uber fresh dank oily hop aroma that is very floral with a lot of sweet citrus notes balancing out the earthy pine. Slight malt presence and a somewhat strong alcohol character. The high ABV is noticeable in he nose and takes away from the hops a bit.

Chewy full body, especially for the style, that is bursting with uber fresh earthy piny and sweet citrus hops. Very floral with lots of lemon peel and grapefruit as well as some tropical mango and pineapple. There is a slight malt backbone providing some balance but this beer is all about the hops. There is a good bit of alcohol heat that takes away from the hops a bit too much for my liking but overall the ABV is decently masked. This beer is still dangerously drnkable but I wish that it had a little less heat. Ive had this beer several times and I love it but I still prefer Elder.

At Capones also. Russian River Draft Promo today. I was lucky enough to have the Younger and Elder side by side. Pours a beautiful shade of orange, and smells right away of a hop explosion. What sets Pliny off from other Imperial IPAs is the hop selection and the blending perfection. This beer just works. It is the gold standard in IPAs. This is what so many others try to be, and cant get to. When you can get this or Elder.... DO IT!

On tap at Capones.  Pours a clear golden color with orange hues.  No head.  Aroma of pine, grapefruit, and hops.  Pleasant and not overpowering.  Flavor of grapefruit, pine, honey and hops.  Very well-balanced, powerful and not overwhelming.  Just beautiful.

The aroma is not overpowering, hops obviously dominating. The clear golden ale is followed by a small head. This IPA reminds me of the 90 minute but more clear notes of bitter and sweet hops. Served at the right temperature at Capones it starts off the morning right.

Growler.  Intensely hoppy nose, massive pine, grapefruit, orange and tropical fruit, with background notes of honey, toast, pineapple, faint alcohol and spruce.  Clear golden amber color, head is initially quite frothy.  Flavor is amazingly hoppy and strong, with hops utterly permeating every aspect of the experience, with huge pine, citrus, peppery alcohol, gigantic bitterness, but somehow not unbalanced, the malts lending a healthy backbone of caramel sweetness and a certain biscuity, toasty character, also some background fruitiness making an appearance.  Warming, resinous mouthfeel, smooth, with a rich, full body.  This is incredible.  More than the sum of its parts.  I savored every drop.  Huge thanks to mreusch!

Freshly tapped at 7:00PM, kicked at 7:16PM at San Diego Brewing Co. (San Diego, CA): Lucky to be the first served customer! I got my hands on two 10oz. glasses and took it all in. Light clear golden in appearance, with a thick white head. Aroma of big pine, citrus and grasses. Practically the entire range of hop aromas are releasing from my glass at one time. Smells delicious, and I have a cold!!! No detection of malts here. The warming effect from massive alcohol intake balances with what would be a palate crusher on bitterness without. Due to this, there are more and more hop nuances coming in as flavor waves throughout my session. Swirling Younger against my palate for at least 60 seconds produces no alcoholic sting whatsoever. What does come from it is a nicely marked light orange flavor sweetness than sipping it cold. Dry hops and florals stay resilient through the lingering finish. At this point I looked around the bar and found that I was the last person to have another full 10oz. glass left. And what perfect timing that Younger gets tapped right as I continue on to my 300th rating! Drinkability: Lives up to the anticipation. Currently my highest rating to date. Pairing: Water. This ale is dangerously drinkable, granted youre not limited to 10oz. glassware. Rebuy: Yep. #300 on 26022010,. DG.

Had this at Horsebrass on Monday.  For a triple IPA it was remarkably smooth and easy to drink.  We were surprised there werent more people there, but it didnt last very long all the same.  A real treat.

Growler shared by jerz at Woodshop 5.0. Pours a clear gold with an orange tinge and a creamy dense white head. Aroma is hugely pineappley/grapefruity with vanilla and a piney herbal character. Flavor is very herbal and bitter, lots of resins for sure. Sweetness comes through only in an orange/lychee hoppiness. Malt? What malt? We dont need no stinkin malt. Even if there was a pound of peated malt in this I wouldnt be able to taste it through the absurd hop whirlwind. I think I used the word "whirlwind" in my PTE review too now that I think about it. Whatever, this beer pulverizes. Ill rerate next year off a proper pint.

Two 2oz tasting at EBF
Appearance : Clear yellow, small head, some lacing.

Aroma : Herbal and leafy hops. Nice mango/passion fruit 

Taste : Fruity passion fruit, leafy hops. Some bitterness and alcohol on the finish. Herbal hops also.

Overall : Truly awesome stuff. Fruity and hoppy. Nice sharp bitterness. Tasted side by side with PtE and SN Hoptimum and this was the best of the three. The balance between the fruitiness and the hops really made it the winner in my case. It felt like the best beer ever. Need to have it another time to be sure of that !

Deep translucent amber, with a pillowy white head.  Amazing aroma!  So much floral hops, has some bite in the nose.  Tastes like piney hops, with a bitter finish that has a slight alcohol burn.  Great beer, but a little rough around the edges.

Clear orange-yellow pour with at ouch of haze.  Sweet fruity tropical fruit hop aroma.  Piny with lots of alcohol.  Sweet initially with a slightly acidic note.  Very bitter hops finish it up with a lots of alcohol.
10 oz. pour on-tap at The Horse Brass.  Just fantastic blending of malty backbone with an up-front hoppy citrusy bitterness.  Not nearly as unbalanced as I expected, but just as good.

2010 growler.  Yet another huge thanks to DuffManSW for hooking this up!  Big, loose white head with great lacing and a nice golden color.  Big juicy melon and citrus  notes in the aroma with hints of honey, honeydew melon, and a distinct skunky homegrown (yeah that kind) quality.  The flavor is a juicy blend of wet hops, melon, grapefruit, tropical fruit, and a mellow bitterness on the finish that just lingers forever.  The body is creamy and medium-full with soft carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2012 Not nearly as good as it used to be... Cant pin point it, but certainly this year was a bigger batch as many places had it in CO! Same brew without that "x" factor or that soul or whatever made it so good! Had it a couple times in the last couple months... just disappointing.

Out of a tulip glass at Rose and Crown in Palo Alto for SF beer week - I got the last pour before the keg blew and would have been devastated had I missed it.  
Amazing hops fly out of the glass and a full, billowing white head.  Color is a brilliant orange-gold.  Mouthfeel is full, and surprisingly smooth for an 11% beer.  Some nice malt backbone that I didnt necessarily expect, and loads and loads of hops, both fruity and piney.  This is such an amazing beer and it so well rounded.
on tap at Malt n Vine, Redmond WA.  WOW - taste was an evolution form carmel malt to a wonderfully balanced hop explosion.  Simply the best IPA Ive enjoyed.  Well done RR!

Sample graciously given by Mark at Bigelos.  My taste buds will take some time to heal up after this sample.  An incredible hop bitterness.  Everything that hops can offer is in there.  A surprising tangerine note along with the other citrus and pine.  A sample was enough for me but what a statement it made!

Finally got to try this elusive brew.  Light golden pour into the glass.  Aroma is FRESH piney hop explosion.  The intensity of the hops tickle my nostrils and really excite me for the first sip.  From the moment this elixir touches my lips I can tell that it was worth the wait .  Incredible fresh piney evergreen  hop flavor with a touch of grapefruit.  A bit of sweet honey ballances out the bitterness.  A HUGE hopbomb with intense bitterness and some ballancing sweetness.  Blows the competition out of the water, the best DIPA out there

Finally got a chance to try the newest number one on Beeradvocate.com.

Poured from the tap into a tasting glass.

The color is a deep dark orange, is clear with a nice finger or two head. Some nice lacing on the glass.

The smell is just hoppy from the start. The is some nice grapefruit and pineapple that comes out first to welcome the aroma into sweet and delicious hop dream.

The taste is pretty hoppy but even balanced with a mellow fruity flavor. There are just a few fruits that cam into mind as I tasted this. A nice banana flavor with some grapefruit flavor mixed with a bit of melon. A wonderful fruit experience.

The feel of this beer is pretty mellow. There is a few points that come out to pronounce themselves but there seems to be less of a kick to the Younger than the Elder and I was really happy to say I was a able to take my time with this beer and enjoy it. Worth the wait and the hype.
EBF session 1. Pours  mixture of a bright golden orange an yellow. The aroma is a mixture of grass, flower, grapefruit, spruce and pine. It was a little cloying and sweet. Vinnie is the MAN

Growler poured into a Sam Adams Pint glass produced a finger worth of white head, that goes to a nice ring of lace that slides down the glass. The body of the brew is a clear golden yellow to orange in color.

The first thing I notice at the cracking of the growler, was the hiss and the aromas of fresh hops. Big pine and cat piss (LOL) along with citrus and grasses. There is a wide rage of hop aromas coming from this one. One of the best noses from a DIPA I have ever smelled.
The flavor can best be described as Elder on steroids. I dont know if its the malts that add balanced to this hop forward brew, or the alcohol warmth. There is a nice light orange flavor sweetness coming from the elixir. With the hop dryness holding back the alcohol warmth in the end. The brew has a medium feel to it with surprisingly good carbonation to it for a growler. A true testament to Derek stately care of this one.

Well I have a growler of this one to cherish for the whole day, and I didnt even have to stand in line at the EBF for it. I will make a few calls to see if anyone want to help finish this but I wont be to sad if I cant find anyone ;-) 
I do know I wont be driving too much today though. Final thoughts... As an east coast guy I wish it was a little more balanced, but it is true to form for an west coast DIPA

Serving type: growler

Had the pleasure of having this on tap at the Brewpub in Santa Rosa, CA a few years back.  To this day it is still my favorite beer. Period. I have nothing but superlatives to say about Pliny the Younger!

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 First, I owe a big thank you to joeneugs for landing this growler for me and shipping it cross-country.  Second, I love the growler glass itself, and everyone who has seen it has commented on it.  As for the beer...pours a clear gold with a linen white head.  The aroma is huge and is loaded with bright and fruity grapefruit, lemon, pineapple and even a bit of melon.  The flavor is malt which is more biscuit and less caramel followed by a total wash of hops goodness that includes fruity grapefruit, lemon and pineapple with just a bit of pine.  Strong hops bitterness at the finish, but the bitterness is not pith, which to my palate is the undoing of many uberhoppy beers.  This beer retains its fruity citrus character throughout.  Fairly smooth on the palate; this beer goes down way too easily.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Overall, superb.

Tap at the Dray in Seattle.

Ah, at last! The Younger. I dont even want to go on and on about the rate, so just some rough impressions: big lovely juice nose, apricot and all the expected citrus,  more fruity and less herbal than the elder brother, gorgeous flavor like drinking some kind of crazy hop liqueur  that could have been a 37% eau de vie of hops what for all the flavor intensity but drank like a 9% IIPA on the tongue. Insane. Tonight was one hell of beer night, is all I can say. First 3767 comes out of nowhere to hit my top 10, and then this one follows it up as one of the all time trophies of my beer hunting career.

Draft at Uber Tavern.  I wasnt expecting to get a chance to try this.  Pours a clear orange gold with a small, sticky white head that left some thin spidery lacing.  Has a lot of visible carbonation to it.  Aroma is big on American hops with all that implies: grass, grapefruit, pine, and floral aromas.  Starts a little caramelly and biscuity, but not as overtly sweet as I would have expected it to be.  Has a long lingering bitter finish full of the aforementioned hoppy aromatics.  I wouldnt place this as my favorite IPA, but I was quite impressed by how incredibly easy to drink this 11% beast is.  I only noticed the alcohol via the effects it had on my empty stomach, and it wasnt too cloying in flavor.  Id still take fresh Elder over this, since I prefer my IPAs more on the dry side, but this was a great experience.

A Mes rate. Hand bottled thanks to Mike. Fuckin hell mate. You really pulled out the big guns here!Clean dark gold, still holding onto a head even after the hand bottling. Aroma is pretty much hands down the best hoppage I have experienced. I cant rattle on here, its just too bloody good. The flavour is just massive. All the tangerine, pine, spruce, grass, citrus and everything else anyone could like about hops. Aromatic as hell. Stunningly crafted. Soooooo incredibly juicy. Its very full in the mouth but the body just carries everything soooooo bloody well. Finishes brutally. The most epic kick in the knackers you can imagine. For once Im lost for words really. I know this is a crap rate. My attention is in my glass...

10 oz pour at Uber Tavern Seattle, WA. The keg was gone in 15 minutes.I dont know if there is such thing as a perfect beer but this is as close as it gets. Pour was a deep golden amber with a small white head. Nose of biscuity caramel malt, grapefruit, orange peel, and of course hops. Taste was big on sweet caramel malt at first transitioning into a wonderful floral hop presence. This is the easiest drinking beer Ive ever had. The 11% was well hidden. A gem in the beer world...thank you RR!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2010 Wow what an amazing beer. Thanks to Mike and Diane for sending this out to DuffmanSW. I lost my notebook with the rating so Im gonna wing it. Poured a clear golden color with beautiful head. Aroma was very very fresh hops, very floral and sweet with lots of pineapple and dank marijuana. Taste was like Elder on steroids with some alcohol present, super sweet and sticky with nice malty balance. Well balanced triple IPA that left a tiny bitterness on the pallet but a great aftertaste. One of my favorites.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Thanks to thewolf for getting his hands on this rarity!

Golden with a lasting and creamy off-white head. Strong aroma of resinous hops, peach and grapefruit. Outstanding use of American hops. Big sweet fruity hop flavour with peach, citrus and pine. Syrup-y sweetness and warm alcohol. It hides the alcohol well, and is very drinkable. But still, its a heavy IPA. If you can drink only one Pliny, this is not the one.

Clear bright amber with a small white head that leaves tiny bits of lazing on the snifter used. Aroma is alittle restrained at lower tempature but opens up after a while in the glass offering sweet perfumey and piney hops with notes of grape, oranges and loads of other citric fruit. The malt character is rather clean and pleasant with an original bisquity caramell blend. Flavor starts out rather sweet with loads of peach, grape and bisquity clean malt but quickly turns fairly dry with big cintric hop notes and a lingering peachy malt sweetness, pine juice and some warming alcohol. Palate is very smooth and the brew goes down way too easy. Big thanks to wavers1 for getting this growler out to me especially considering the stress surrounding the release!

Growler. [thank you soooo much, joenugs]
Pours coppery golden with only a slight haze. Small, staying, creamy, white head. Aroma is pure hoppy goodness. Piney, resiny, grapefruit, citrus, apple zest. Truly remarkable. Medium carbonation, dry and lovely creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is dry, bitter, softly vinious. Piney, grapefruity, resiny, grassy and light perfumey hops. Some heather and apples as well. Super hoppy. Not as simple or as elegant as the "Elder", but there is power en masse! World-class!

100th rating and it had to be special. Finally!! I got my half pint from Falling Rock. Well worth the wait and if they can up production I dare say this could become the new standard in the IIPA world. Great overall balance much different from PTE as far as hop flavors go. Mainly pineapple with a splash of grapefruit and a soft semi dry finish. While they may share the same title PTE and PTY are very different and depending on your preferance for hop flavors will be what draws you one way or the other IMO. I can say however without a doubt that I prefer PTY and it is at the moment my favorite IPA/IIPA hands down.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Mini glass at tapping event at the Tap Room, best beer bar in PB.  This young buck pours a similar hue as his old man, although Id say perhaps a twinge of copper dancing within the gold, less cloudy as well.  Aroma is hoppier with a juicy yet unidentified fruit along for the ride.  Initial palate shot is hardcore...hops, pine, citrus, hops and yes...a bit of alcohol.  This one grabs hold of your tongue with bitterness, a sexy bitterness that lets you know its a triple IPA alright...but its still immensely enjoyable.  

Tap Room had 2 kegs (5 gallon) tonight.  Tapped them at 5:00 and 8:00.  They were gone by 5:15 and 8:15.  My only regret is that I didnt order more.

Tiny taster fromt the taproom tapping.. 8pm SHARP!! pours a very light almost crystal copper with a poppy, potent, persuasive aroma that permeates above the rim as if it were a Lebron James throwdown..exactly.. AUTHORITY.. thats what hits my palate.. pushy but not pretentious the full bodiedness erupts and holds court.. at first the alcohol holds the hops hostage but as I let the beer reach room temperature the alcohol subsides and the hops settle into a sensible sweetness..  FUERTE and aggressive but intimate at the same time.  It may have almost been a little much for me which is why I didnt rate it higher.  I feel like I enjoyed the Port Brewing double IPA, Mongo, just a bit more.. Still a well constructed Imperial all the way around..

On tap at Toronado San Diego.  Strong amber in the glass with hint of haze.  One finger eggshell head drops to sticky-ass lace.  Nose is sharp hops to light funk.  No, not light funk.  Funky ass funk.  George Clinton and the p-funk all-stars funky.  Big burst in the front of the mouth.  No sweetness at first.  Hint of sweetness in the middle before bitter and gooey end.  It was worth the hassle of driving down mid-week on short notice after being shut out at an earlier establishment.

Growler shared by mreusch. Thanks! Served in a Boulevard Tank 7 glass. Poured a deep gold with a thin white head. Massive piney hop aroma. Flavor is dominated by hop bitterness as you would expect, but there is a solid malt base without being sweet. Very drinkable for the abv, alcohol was not very evident. Lots of hops without being too green in the flavor. Nice mouthfeel, medium to full bodied. Believe the hype.

Huge thanks to Baker(wavers1) for being so kind, and sending this along with so many awesome brews.  Took this to our local Tuesday get together to share.  From the growler pours a slightly hazy bright gold with a medium off white head.  Aroma is all over the hop spectrum.  Pine resin, some spruce tip, light citrus notes.  Flavor is full on hop.  I dont think its entirely one sided, there is enough light doughy malt to balance, but its more or less a blank canvass for the hops to shine on.  Strong bitter dry hop finish with pine dominating.  So good and not a trace of the 11 percent until I felt drunk 5 mins later.  Thanks again Baker!

Tasted this tonight at a local tasting. My buddy Keith got this through a trade and he is awesome enough to share with us. Pours a really clear yellow to light orange with some Hop residue in my glass, yep hops I say. I am not a great smeller, but I do smell a ton of hops. So, for a normal person, you would smell a mega ton, I bet. The taste is very floral and not over bittering, which is great in my book. I am not a bitter freak, I like hop flavors. Wish we could get this in Florida year round.

Snifter - thanks Junko & Sean! The hype and rarity of PtY makes it hard to stay objective in a review.  Really mild but deep citrus & flowers aroma only comes out with a generous swirl. Modest white head keeps going to the last drop, With lacing a plenty. Flavor is light malts and stealth hops intensity. Spicy, almost pilsner style lightness on the tongue. Finish is dry in the extreme. Then the bitterness hits you and lasts indefinitely.
floral, grass, citrus, herbs, alcohol, golden, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, very bitter, average carbonation, bitter, long finish,

Rating #500. Growler, Big thanks to AskDrTodd for the share.  Poured a clear slightly orange golden color with a large foamy white head.  This beer absolutely has the market cornered when it comes to balance both in aroma and in flavor.  The nose is powerful but not at all overpowering, beautiful hop profile, starts with flowery piney grassy notes which are shortly followed by balanced notes of citrus, pineapple, peach, caramel and toffee.  Full body with a smooth, silky mouthfeel with ample carbonation.  The flavor of this is really a celebration of hops, primary resinous notes of pine and grass on a strong toffee/caramel background and perfectly blended with big notes of citrus and peach.  Overall slightly sweet with medium hop bitterness and very well hidden alcohol.  Finishes with a very clean mouthfeel somewhat sticky and a decent amount of lingering bitterness.  I found myself wishing that growler would never end.  Thanks Todd!

Admittedly this is my favorite style of beer and PTY is one of the best.  Very aromatic with massive citrusy hops overpowering the senses.  Grapefruit and pine resonate throughout the beer (on the nose, tongue and palate).  Finishes with a slight bitterness.  Awesome beer.

a special thanks to Wavers1 for this growler.  please, beleive the hype, this beer is makes me want to do flips.  popping the top off the growler sends an immediate bouquet of dank and hops and piney resin.  the appearance is beautiful with a head that lasts forever.  the aromas are wonderful piney, a little citrus and throw in the best dank your medicinal provider can give you.  the tastes lingers forever and the alcohol is well hidden.  i will do everything to get another growler of this next year.

Ahh, the elusive Younger. Was it worth the wait? Quite possibly.  But that is not to say that a good pint of PtE isnt just as good, with a tenth of the amount of trouble to get.  Aroma is hugely hoppy, lots of grapefruit, tropical fruits, lemon zest, wonderful.  Mouthfeel is fairly full as far as DIPAs go, almost a bit oily.  Flavor starts and finishes with the most rounded, balanced yet assertive hop assault Ive ever tasted.  Alcohol adds heft to this beer, but is not intrusive. Excellent, but as a complete drinker Ill give the edge to Elder overall.

Growler shared by mreusch. Pour is a light hazed golden yellow with a one inch white head. Aroma of dank, fresh, resinous hops and a nice caramel biscuit malt balanced in. The hops are super fresh, super soft, just throwing off a ton of hop oil. Taste is immediately the resinous, big, leafy hops, along with a bright malty sweetness and evident alcohol. Taste is brash and hoppy, bright and resiny sweet. Not as balanced as the nose, but I am sure this is exactly what they intended. Palate is medium, perhaps even a touch towards light bodied. Carbonation is just right, with a dry finish - with residual alcohol heat along with the oily resins of the hops.  This is certainly a hop bomb, but also has a nice malt backbone so it came off balanced nicely.  Thanks for sharing this rare one Matt, it was really a lot of fun to try.

Had on tap at Hollingsheads Deli - first keg of the day.  Pours golden yellow with slight head which persists for a long time.  Slight lacing.  Aroma of hops and some more hops and little more hops.  For a triple IPA though, this beer is amazingly smooth.  A bit oily, but very drinkable and a very pleasant beer.  Finishes very bitter with a hint of sweetness - not too harsh - just about right for this type of beer.  The ratings most likely are boosted by the difficulty in finding the beer and the mystique around it, but it truly is an amazing beer - able to pack all those wonderful hop flavors into a drink that is able to contain the bitterness in a smooth, drinkable beer.

[Growler] with a huge thanks to kmweaver! Thanks again, Ken! Pours a hazy vibrant copper color with a moderate off-white head. Initial whiffs give loads of resinous hops - tons of grapefruit, pine sap and needles, peach, mango, orange, and theres also a bit of malt in the background there. Flavor is remarkably hoppy with citrus, pine, some metallic character from the alcohol, and a huge bitterness at the end with the malt just barely keeping it together. This beer is huge and abrasive - not terribly drinkable, but immensely enjoyable. The quintessential west coast hop bomb.

Draft, Russian River. Pliny the Younger 2010 release. Out of a 10oz pub glass, another great brew by RR. Excellent IIIPA very well balanced, intense aroma, intense flavor and intense bittnerness. well worth the standing in line for. Glad I bought a growler of it as well

Growler thanks to joeneugs! Pours a clear gold with a thin white head that laced a bit. Aroma is full pine and grassy notes with a slight undertone of sweet grains and a bit of honey. Flavor is even more full of hops with pine and grass notes through out with a bit of honey and sweet grains coming in at the finish.

Growler shared by maltomeal at the Feb. Houston RB tasting-thanks for getting this for us Bill. Bright gold filtered with a big white head. Nose of course is super hops, citrusy, sweet but not harsh. Bitterness hits you first, then the hops that seemed sweet come on later. The alcohol presence comes in at the end. Very smooth palate and too easy to drink considering the high ABV. Excellent beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Growler courtesy of Kevin at Grape and Gourmet. Huge thanks for this! Pretty gold pour. No head. Resinous legs run down the glass. Strong hoppy resinous aroma. Caramel sticks out as well. Taste is strong hops, big pine citrus/grapefruit, and caramel. Strong warmth, resinous with little carbonation in the body. Overall is medium-full. Ends with more pine, resinous hops, light caramel, grapefruit, and citrus oils. Delicious!

Growler shared by Kan. Thanks!! Pours a nice lighter copper, decent haze, with an offwhite head that bubbles and chains, laces lightly. Aromas are a huge melange of citrus and tropical fruits, lemon and grapefruit rind, florals, and faint pine. The tropical and grapefruit really smack you in the face intensely. A lighter malt body, the hops take dominant fruity hold. Initial is not overly in your face, a smoothed fruity experience, very good bitterness with orange, grapefruit, mango, lemon, florals, lighter pale and caramel malts, the alcohol is hidden near perfectly, the bitterness is firm but not offensive, balanced well with bitterness and sweetness in near perfect balance, smooth, a touch soapy. The bitterness really grows to a cresendo. Lemon and grapefruit rind, tropical fruits, a decent sweet edge. This was one of the best DIPAs Ive had, highly bitter but balanced well.

Growler shared by AJ.  Thanks AJ!  Pours clear orange color with thick off white head.  Aroma is citrus, simcoe hops with grapefruit rind, and some resinous stinky citrus hops.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is an explosion of flavor.  It follows the nose nicely and I can detect layers of resinous hop goodness.  Upfront its citrus, then comes simcoe citrus, followed by pine sol flavor, and coats my mouth with hop resins and finishes with a touch of heat.  Overall the alcohol is hidden well and I do detect a touch of alcohol in the finish.  With more hops.  Wonderful beer.  Thanks AJ!

From a growler shared at Grape & Gourmets 4th Anniversary (thanks to GandGKevin).  Golden orange pour.  HUGE hop aroma that I could honestly smell with the glass 2 feet under my nose.  The hop aroma is of pine and grapefruit rind.  Bitter hop flavor but overall surprisingly smooth and easy to drink.  Very little to find fault with.  Luckily I prefer Pliny the Elder ever so slightly if I were forced to compare the two.

Huge thanks to Maltomeal for bringing back a growler of this incredible beer. Pours a lovely chedder orange with thin, bubbley rocky head. The most wonderful nose of hops, cirtus, honey, flowers and hop spice. Flavor follows suit with some great citrus and hop layers. Malt is there, but really just to hold the hops and carry through to a fantastic finish...clean and leaving you wanting more. Amazing. Thanks for sharing Bill.

Ive been following this beer all week (San Francisco Beer Week!) The release, IIPA fest, local beer bars, I cant seem to get enough! One of the few special releases that lives up to the hype. It pours a brilliantly clear shimmering gold color with a small off white head. You dont have to go looking for the aroma. It attacks you as you raise your glass. It has everything, florals, citrus, pine, hugely resinous, with a caramel background. Very fresh, juicy, and potent. The flavor really dances around your palate with citrus, some tropical fruit, resin, and pine. I dont really taste any malt flavors in here, but the fruity hops lend a very nice sweetness throughout the beer that balances it a little. This is super fresh tasting and powerful. I sampled this at the Bistro IIPA fest next to about 10 other beers and it knocked the socks off every one. Its a world classic for sure.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2010 Growler- graciously sent by wavers1- thanks baker.  It arrived the friday after it was released at russian river.  perfect.  growler pours a clear golden orange with a small offwhite head.  aroma of orangepeel, pineapple. lemon zest,  hibiscus, and caramel.  Flavor is quite piney up front with a healthy dose of sweet caramel behind it.  THis was tasted side by side by side with blind pig and elder- bonuses from baker.   Honestly, ratings aside, the blind pig is my favorite.  All of them are great, but blind pig is the only one I would want to drink on a regular basis.
